title: 114_s903
content: The text discusses the amendment of the 1986 Internal Revenue Code and provides a table of contents for the Act, including sections related to taxpayer access to the United States Tax Court and the administration of the Tax Court. The text outlines procedures for judicial conduct and disability, administration of the judicial conference, and clarification regarding the United States Tax Court. It also addresses the filing period for interest abatement cases in the Tax Court. The amendment to subsection (h) of section 6404 changes the heading to "Judicial Review" and specifies the timeline for bringing an action for interest abatement in the Tax Court. The amendments made by this section apply to claims for abatement of interest filed after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 102 amends section 7463 to allow small tax cases seeking interest abatement under $50,000 to petition the Tax Court. The effective date applies to pending and new cases after the enactment of the Act. In section 7482(b), amendments are made regarding petitions under different sections, including specifying the legal residence of the petitioner. Effective date provisions are also included. The amendments made by this section apply to petitions filed after the enactment of this Act, without affecting existing court proceedings. SEC. 104. Suspension of running of period for filing petition of spousal relief and collection cases. SEC. 104 amends subsection (e) of section 6015 by adding a new paragraph that suspends the period for filing a petition in title 11 cases for spousal relief. This amendment applies to petitions filed under section 6015(e). The amendment in section 104 suspends the period for filing a petition in title 11 cases for spousal relief under section 6015(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This amendment applies to petitions filed under section 6015(e) after the enactment of this Act. Amendments are made to subsection (d) of section 6330 regarding collection proceedings, including changes to the process of appealing determinations to the Tax Court. The running of the period for filing a petition in title 11 cases is suspended for individuals prohibited from filing under paragraph (1). The amendments apply to petitions filed under section 6330 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 after the enactment of this Act. Subsection (c) of section 6320 is amended accordingly. SEC. 105 amends Section 7453 to apply the Federal Rules of Evidence. The effective date is for proceedings after the enactment of this Act. TITLE II introduces SEC. 201 on Judicial Conduct and Disability Procedures in the United States Tax Court Administration. The Tax Court will establish procedures for filing complaints regarding the conduct of judges, with powers similar to a judicial council. Referral and review processes will follow the grounds for judge removal. The Tax Court will conduct hearings and have the authority to pay fees and allowances, as well as award reimbursement for expenses. Complaints regarding judge conduct will be referred to the President for consideration. The Tax Court will conduct hearings, pay fees, and award reimbursements. Complaints about judge conduct will be referred to the President. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part II of subchapter C of chapter 76. The amendments made by this section regarding judicial conduct and disability procedures apply to proceedings after 180 days from the enactment of the Act. Section 7470 introduces new sections related to administration in Part III of subchapter C of chapter 76. The Tax Court has authority for management, administration, and expenditure of funds, similar to other U.S. courts. The Judicial Conference is established under section 7470A. The Tax Court's chief judge may convene an annual judicial conference for judges and magistrate judges to discuss court business and suggest ways to improve justice administration. The court can charge a registration fee for non-judicial participants to cover conference expenses. The Tax Court's chief judge may convene an annual judicial conference for judges and magistrate judges to discuss court business and suggest ways to improve justice administration. The court can charge a registration fee for non-judicial participants to cover conference expenses. Section 7473 is amended to allow fees collected to defray conference expenses. SEC. 7473 states that all fees received by the Tax Court will be deposited into a special fund to support the court's operation. Additionally, the table of sections is amended to include new items related to court administration and judicial conferences. SEC. 301 clarifies that the Tax Court is independent of the executive branch.
